questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of chronic bloody diarrhea undergoes a colonoscopy. The procedure reveals continuous colonic mucosal inflammation extending proximally from the rectum to the cecum, and notable inflammation of the terminal ileum. Backwash ileitis is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcerative colitis

 

Option B:

 

Ulcerative colitis commonly presents with continuous colonic inflammation that may extend proximally in a continuous fashion from the rectum. When it involves the terminal ileum, this is referred to as backwash ileitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, "skip" areas of inflammation, which can involve any part of the GI tract from the mouth to the anus. While ileal involvement is common in Crohn's, the continuous inflammation pattern described does not typically occur.

 

Option C. Colonic carcinoma may lead to secondary inflammation due to obstruction or invasion but does not cause backwash ileitis.

 

Option D. Ileal polyps may be a feature of various polyposis syndromes but are not associated with backwash ileitis, which is specifically related to inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Backwash ileitis refers to the extension of inflammatory changes from the colon into the terminal ileum and is associated with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease, colonic carcinoma, or ileal polyps.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 801

choices.text: Commonest site is ascending colon and cecum

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a two-week history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colonoscopy reveals several ulcers in the cecum and ascending colon.  The patient has a travel history to an area with poor sanitation. All are true about amoebic ulcer except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perforation is common

 

Option C:

 

Contrary to this statement, perforation is not a common complication of amoebic ulcers; it is relatively rare and suggests other underlying or superimposed pathologies if present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The cecum and ascending colon are indeed the most common sites for amoebic ulcers, matching the patient's colonoscopic findings.

 

Option B. Flask-shaped ulcers are indicative of amoebic colitis, where the invading Entamoeba histolytica causes deep ulcers with undermined edges.

 

Option D. The histology of amoebic colitis typically shows minimal inflammation, as the trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica cause cell lysis and necrosis without inducing a significant inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoebic ulcers are typically seen in the colon, particularly in the cecum and ascending colon. They are associated with amoebic colitis caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. These ulcers are usually deep with undermined edges, giving them the flask-shaped appearance. Perforation is not a common feature of amoebic ulcers

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 796

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. A colonoscopy reveals ulcerations. Biopsies are taken, and the patient is diagnosed with amoebic colitis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The most common site for amoebiasis:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cecum

 

Option C:

 

Amoebic ulcers are typically seen in the colon, particularly in the cecum and ascending colon. They are associated with amoebic colitis caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. These ulcers are usually deep with undermined edges, giving them the flask-shaped appearance.

 

The cecum, followed by the ascending colon, is the most frequent location for amoebic ulcers within the colon due to factors such as stasis and bacterial content, providing a conducive environment for Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The sigmoid colon can be affected by amoebic colitis, but it is not the most common site of amoebic involvement in the colon.

 

Option B. Amoebiasis may involve the transverse colon, but such involvement is less common than in the cecum and ascending colon.

 

Option D. The liver is indeed the most common extraintestinal site affected by amoebiasis, often resulting from hematogenous spread from the intestinal lesion, but within the intestine itself, the cecum is the most commonly affected site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the most common site for amoebiasis within the intestine, presenting typically with deep ulcers that have undermined edges, often giving a flask-shaped appearance.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /795

questions.text: All are complication of typhoid ulcers except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stricture formation

 

Option B:

 

Stricture formation is not usually seen with enteric fever. It is a feature with intestinal tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Perforation: Perforation is a well-known complication of typhoid ulcers. The ulcers can penetrate through the intestinal wall, leading to perforation and potentially causing peritonitis.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Typhoid ulcers can cause bleeding, and hemorrhage is a recognized complication. Ulceration and erosion of blood vessels within the intestinal wall can result in gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option D. Sepsis: Perforation of typhoid ulcers can allow the entry of bacteria into the abdominal cavity, leading to sepsis. Sepsis is a severe, life-threatening complication that can result from the spread of bacteria and their toxins.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 791

choices.text: Crohn’s disease
Ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Granulomatous inflammation is found in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crohn’s disease

Option A:

Characterized by granulomatous inflammation, which is one of the key histopathological features that can involve any segment of the GI tract. It is known for transmural inflammation, skip lesions, and granuloma formation.

Explanation:

Option B. Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the colonic mucosa with continuous lesions, but without the granulomas typical of Crohn's disease.

Option C. Amoebiasis, caused by Entamoeba histolytica, can result in ulcerative lesions within the GI tract but does not produce granulomatous inflammation.

Option D. Giardiasis, caused by the protozoan Giardia lamblia, typically results in malabsorption and diarrhea after affecting the small intestine, but without granulomas.

Educational Objective:

Granulomatous inflammation is a specific histopathological finding that supports the diagnosis of Crohn's disease and is not typically found in ulcerative colitis, amoebiasis, or giardiasis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 801

choices.text: Mainly affects ileum
Multiple ulcer and transverse
Perforation occurs at 3rd week
Perforation treated by surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a week-long history of fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. She has a history of recent travel to a region endemic for typhoid fever. On examination, she is febrile and has diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory studies show leukopenia and blood cultures are pending. Which of the following features is incorrect regarding the typical presentation of typhoid ulcers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple ulcer and transverse

Option B:

Typhoid ulcers are typically longitudinal, running parallel to the long axis of the bowel; the statement that they are transverse is incorrect.

Explanation:

Option A. The ileum is the most common site of typhoid ulcers caused by Salmonella typhi, which matches the clinical and imaging findings in this case.

Option C. Perforation, although a severe complication, does indeed typically occur in the third week of illness in untreated cases of typhoid fever.

Option D. When perforation occurs, surgical intervention is necessary to manage the patient and prevent severe complications like peritonitis and sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid ulcers are longitudinal along the axis of the bowel rather than transverse, which is a distinguishing feature from other types of bowel ulcers.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 791

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with a prolonged history of abdominal pain, weight loss, and night sweats. A colonoscopy is performed, showing thickened mucosa and ulceration. Biopsy reveals caseating granulomas. Which of the following is the commonest site of intestinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileum

Option C:

The ileum, particularly the ileocecal region, is the most commonly affected area in intestinal tuberculosis because of the high density of lymphoid tissue and the slower transit time allowing more prolonged contact of the bacilli with the mucosa.

Explanation:

Option A. The stomach can be involved in gastrointestinal tuberculosis, but it is a relatively rare site of infection due to the bactericidal properties of gastric acid.

Option B. The jejunum can be affected by tuberculosis, but it is not as common as the ileum due to the latter's greater abundance of lymphoid tissue.

Option D. The colon may be involved, but it is generally secondary to the spread from the ileocecal region, which is the primary site of involvement.

Educational Objective:

The ileum is the most common site of gastrointestinal tuberculosis, especially the terminal ileum and the cecum.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/373

choices.text: Widal test
Stool culture
Urine culture

questions.text: In the clinical assessment of a patient suspected to have typhoid fever, which diagnostic test is most appropriate in the first week of illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blood culture

Option D:

  • Remember the acronym BASU for blood, antibody, stool and urine for making the di­agnosis in the 1st/2nd/3rd and 4th week respectively.
  • Perforation of a typhoid ulcer usually occurs during the third week and is occasionally the first sign of the dis­ease.

Blood cultures are the most reliable diagnostic test in the first week of typhoid fever, as the bacteria can be isolated from the bloodstream before serological tests become positive and before the bacteria are excreted in stool or urine.

Explanation:

Option A. The Widal test detects the presence of agglutinating antibodies against O and H antigens of Salmonella typhi, which generally do not appear until the end of the first week at the earliest.

Option B. Stool cultures may be positive for S. typhi, but they are more commonly used for diagnosis in the second or third week when the bacteria begin to shed in the stool.

Option C. Urine cultures for S. typhi are typically not positive until the third or fourth week of illness.

Educational Objective:

Blood culture is the diagnostic test of choice for typhoid fever in the first week of illness, as it has the highest sensitivity during this early stage of infection.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with typhoid fever, at what point in the disease course is intestinal perforation most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3rd

Option C:

Perforation of typhoid ulcer usually occurs during 3rd week.

The third week is when the risk of perforation is highest due to maximum bowel wall necrosis and ulceration.

Explanation:

Option A. The first week of typhoid fever is characterized by bacteremia without the localized intestinal pathology necessary to cause perforation.

Option B. By the second week, the typhoid ulcers are formed, but they typically have not yet reached the severity required to cause perforation.

Option D. If untreated, the disease can progress, and complications can occur in the fourth week, but the third week is most notorious for the risk of perforation.

Educational Objective:

The third week of the disease course is when perforation of a typhoid ulcer is most likely to occur, as a result of deepening ulcers and necrosis in the intestinal wall.

 

Ref: Bailey 25/e p1174

choices.text: Crypt loss
Crypt branching

questions.text: In the histological examination of a biopsy from a patient with a confirmed diagnosis of ulcerative colitis (UC), which finding is characteristically observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptitis

Option A:

Cryptitis refers to the inflammation of the crypts of Lieberkühn in the colon. This is a common finding in UC and indicates active disease.

The pathology in ulcerative colitis typically involves distortion of crypt architecture, inflammation of crypts (cryptitis), frank crypt abscess, and hemorrhage or in¬flammatory cells in the lamina propria.

Explanation:

Option B. Crypt loss can occur in UC, particularly in chronic or advanced disease, as a result of ongoing inflammation.

Option C. Crypt branching is a regenerative change more often seen in Crohn's disease, reflecting repetitive injury and attempted repair, and is not characteristic of UC.

Option D. Proliferating mucosa suggests active regeneration, which is not a defining feature of UC. UC typically leads to mucosal atrophy and loss due to chronic inflammation.

Educational Objective:

Cryptitis, or inflammation of the crypts, is a hallmark histopathological feature seen in ulcerative colitis, which reflects active inflammation within the colonic mucosa.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 802

choices.text: Diffuse distribution of pseudopolyps
Mucosal edema
Crypt abscesses
Lymphoid aggregates in the mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following would be the best morphological feature to distinguish ulcerative colitis from Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffuse distribution of pseudopolyps

Option A:

The presence of a diffuse distribution of pseudopolyps without skip areas is more characteristic of UC, which typically involves the colon in a continuous pattern from the rectum proximally.

Explanation:

Option B. Mucosal edema is a non-specific finding and can occur in both UC and CD, so it is not helpful in distinguishing between the two diseases.

Option C. Crypt abscesses are seen in UC but can also be present in CD, and therefore, are not definitive for differentiating between the two.

Option D. Lymphoid aggregates form in response to chronic inflammation and can be seen in both UC and CD, thus they are not distinctive for either condition.

Educational Objective:

A diffuse distribution of pseudopolyps is more indicative of ulcerative colitis, which affects the colon continuously, as opposed to Crohn's disease, which typically has a patchy distribution of disease due to skip lesions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 802

choices.text: It is separate and distinct from ulcerative colitis
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Rectum spared in 50% patients with large bowel involvement

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Crohnâ€™s disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rectum spared in 50% patients with large bowel involvement

 

Option D:

 

Crohn's disease can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus.  Skip lesions can occur but is not accurate to suggest that sparing of rectum is seen in exactly 50% of cases

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crohn's disease is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas, particularly in the submucosa.

 

Option B. Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis have differences in terms of distribution and nature of inflammation even though both of them are types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

 

Option C. Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease and is associated with a more severe course of the disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

Skip lesions are seen with Crohnâ€™s disease and rectum is usually spared in this condition.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 801

questions.text: Two identical specimen of the intestine obtained following colectomy shows on examination hemorrhagic cobblestone appearance; one of them however shows longitudinal grooving. It is likely to be a specimen of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Crohnâ€™s disease  

 

Option D:

 

Crohnâ€™s disease is known for its transmural inflammation, which can result in a cobblestone appearance and longitudinal grooving or fissures, in contrast to the other conditions listed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by a continuous pattern of colonic involvement that is usually limited to the mucosal layer and does not feature the cobblestoning or longitudinal grooves typical of Crohnâ€™s disease.

 

Option B. Ischemic colitis often results from vascular insufficiency and can cause ulcerations, but it is not associated with the typical cobblestone appearance or longitudinal grooving of Crohn's disease.

 

Option C. Familial polyposis syndromes, including familial adenomatous polyposis, present with numerous polyps, not with the cobblestone mucosa or longitudinal grooves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemorrhagic cobblestone appearance and longitudinal grooving are distinctive morphological features of Crohnâ€™s disease, indicative of its transmural inflammatory process.

 

Crohnâ€™s vs Ulcerative colitis:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /801

choices.text: Ulcerative colitis
Crohn’s disease
Carcinoma colon

questions.text: Continuous involvement of colonic mucosa is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulcerative colitis

Option A:

Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that uniformly affects the colonic mucosa, always involving the rectum and extending proximally to a variable extent.

Explanation:

Option B. Crohn’s disease has a discontinuous pattern of involvement and can affect any segment of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus, which is not a continuous mucosal involvement.

Option C. Carcinoma colon presents with a localized mass or lesion, and while it can cause inflammation, it does not result in a continuous pattern like in ulcerative colitis.

Option D. Colonic polyps are isolated mucosal abnormalities and, like carcinoma, do not cause continuous inflammation along the colon.

Educational Objective:

Continuous mucosal involvement, starting in the rectum and extending proximally in a continuous fashion, is a hallmark feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /p800

questions.text: A 50-year-young lady Fatima had been receiving antibiotics for severe folliculitis. She develops fever, toxicity, and severe diarrhoea. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomembranous colitis

 

Option B:

 

Pseudomembranous colitis is strongly associated with recent antibiotic use, which disturbs normal gut flora and may allow the overgrowth of C. difficile. It commonly presents with diarrhea, fever, and leukocytosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis is possible, especially after antibiotic use, but is more likely to occur in the immunocompromised and does not have the strong association with antibiotics as seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Option C. Ulcerative colitis typically presents with chronic symptoms of colitis and is unlikely to be triggered by a course of antibiotics.

 

Option D. Whipple disease is less likely given the acute presentation and association with antibiotic usage, and it usually presents with more systemic features over a longer period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomembranous colitis, often caused by C. difficile infection, is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who develops severe diarrhea, fever, and toxicity after treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

 

Overgrowth of Clostridioides (Clostridium) difficile in the colon.

 

  • Antibiotics wipe out normal gut flora â†’ C. difficile proliferates.
  • C. difficile produces toxins A and B â†’ damage colonic mucosa.

 

What actually happens in the colon:

 

  • Toxins â†’ mucosal necrosis and inflammation.
  • Formation of pseudomembranes:
    • Yellow-white plaques of fibrin, inflammatory cells, necrotic debris.
    • Seen on colonoscopy: classic finding.
  • The disease is called:
    • Pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Clinical presentation:

 

  • Begins a few days to weeks after antibiotics.
  • Profuse watery diarrhea (can be bloody).
  • Fever, abdominal pain.
  • Leukocytosis (high WBC count).
  • Can progress to fulminant colitis, toxic megacolon.
  • Common antibiotics that predispose: clindamycin (classic), also cephalosporins, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, etc. 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 793
